RANsquawk US Market Wrap - US MARKET WRAP – 16 November 2018: Trump positive on China trade; Fed’s Clarida warns on global growth
content:
US MARKET WRAP – 16 November 2018: Trump positive on China trade; Fed’s Clarida warns on global growth

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, treasuries up, dollar down, crude up.
* REAR-VIEW: Trump says he may not have to impose further tariffs on China, Stephen Barclay named Brexit Secretary; Key ministers back PM May, Fed’s Clarida strikes dovish tone, Fed’s Kaplan cautious on outlook, Evans no longer sees need for accommodation; US Industrial Production miss; ECB’s Draghi reiterates overall risks to growth broadly-balanced.
* NEXT WEEK: EU leaders summit, EC on Italian budget, Hungary Rate Decision, RBA Minutes, New Zealand PPI, Japanese Trade Balance, German PPI, German GDP, Flash PMIs, US Building Permits & Housing Starts, Canadian CPI, Thanksgiving on Thursday.

* TRADE: US President Trump said China wants to make a deal on trade, but not acceptable as it is now. Crucially, Trump said he may not have to impose further tariffs on China, and hopefully a deal can be made, though he once again said that trade must be reciprocal. China list is pretty complete, "4/5 things" left off. Risk markets welcomed the news, with ES rallying after the headlines, on optimism that Trump and Xi will make progress at the G20 on trade, though reports earlier in the week suggested the two would focus on the ‘big picture’ themes. Later, officials reportedly walked back from Trump’s comments, saying he was expressing ‘general optimism’, and US had not reached a deal with China, comments which saw some of the risk-on moves pare back.

* BREXIT: Environment Minister Michael Gove, UK ministers Fox, Grayling, Mourdant, Leadsom, have not resigned from the government and they have pledged to support PM May in achieving the best Brexit outcome. Stephen Barclay was appointed Brexit Secretary after Raab resigned and Gove rejected the position on Thursday; note Barclay is a Brexiteer and a supporter of leaving the EU. On the confidence vote, some reports suggested that the 48 letters, the threshold to trigger a no confidence vote in PM May, has been reached whilst others confirmed that 22 Conservative Party MPs have now publicly declared their intent to submit motions against the PM with the vote likely to be triggered next week. In related comments, Eurosceptic Minister Steve Baker stated that they are not too far off the required letters to trigger a leadership challenge. Elsewhere, sources told the FT that Brexiteers in the Cabinet meeting on the weekend are looking at changing text of the Withdrawal Agreement to amend the backstop. Looking ahead, the EU Brexit schedule has been agreed; the special Brexit meeting EU27 ambassadors has been scheduled for Sunday whilst the special Brexit EU27 Europe ministers Wheels in motion for Sunday 25 November summit has been set for Monday.

* FED: Fed Vice Chair Clarida took note that the IMF recently trimmed its global growth view, and added that the Fed takes into account global factors when setting policy, leading many to interpret that he may favour slowing the pace of rate hikes amid slowing global growth. He urged the Fed to take an especially data-dependent approach to policy. On rates, he said being at neutral would make sense and estimates that this level is between 2.5% and 3.5%, noting they are currently below that range. Clarida still sees room to run in the labour market; he acknowledged some volatility around stock markets at the moment but there is no clear signal. Fed's Kaplan (dove, non-voter) appeared more cautious on the economy’s outlook stating that increasing debt to GDP is a tailwind for now but will become a headwind in the future. He added global growth will be a little bit of a headwind and may spill to the US. Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) no longer sees the need for accommodation; the US economy is doing well and expects 3.25% GDP growth this year and 3.5% next year. He noted that wages have increased but not as much as he was looking for. He sees the current rate a little bit below neutral, stressing that getting to neutral is the "first order job" for the Fed. Fed's Harker (non-voter, centrist) does not believe that a December rate hike is prudent; says there is rising uncertainty about the outlook

* ECB: ECB's Draghi noted that the current slowdown has raised questions about the strength of the growth outlook and seeing a temporary soft patch. He added that in December “we will be better placed” to make a full assessment of the risks to growth and inflation. He still sees the overall risks to the growth outlook as broadly balanced. ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said that monetary policy should be effective in achieving the inflation mandate and leave enough room for market activity; he sees no reason to depart from the pre-crisis monetary policy framework.

* ITALY: EU's Dombrovskis reiterated that the Italian budget "significantly" deviates from their commitments, and Rome is "openly" challenging the rules. He added that contagion is limited, and the policy is worrying investors and pushing bond yields higher. He believes credit conditions in Italy are worsening, which is slowing the banking sectors' recovery. In response, Italy's government has told the EU the risks to its public finances are limited and is confident the recent rise in government bond yields is "manageable". Italian Deputy PM Di Maio said to be in agreement with ECB President Draghi that the nation must lower its debt.

* US INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION softened a little in October rising by 0.1%, below the expected 0.2%. Looking at the breakdown, utilities output was down 0.5% while the mining sector slowed 0.3% following the recent oil prices slump. On the flip side, gains were led by manufacturing production which posted gains for the 5th consecutive amid an increase in primary metals and machinery.  

* SPX +0.2% at 2736, NDX -0.3% at 6867, DJI +0.5% at 25413. SECTORS: Energy +1.1%, Materials +1.0%, Industrials -0.0%, Cons Discretionary -0.5%, Cons Staples +0.2%, Healthcare +0.9%, Financials +0.1%, Tech -0.1%, Telecoms -0.4%, Utilities +1.3%. Pacific Gas & Electric (PGE) surged back today, after its recent sharp selloff, due to California utility regulators saying it was unlikely the co. would become bankrupt; this also led to gains in local competitor Edison International (EIX). EOG Resources (EOG) was a top mover after an upgrade at Credit Suisse.  T-Mobile (TMUS) traded higher on the back of reports it could close its acquisition of Sprint (S) earlier than expected. NVIDIA (NVDA) nosedived following it reporting revenue beneath estimates, spreading wider pessimism across semiconductor stocks such as Advanced Micron Devices (AMD) and Micron Technology (MU). Nordstrom (JWN) dipped after missing EPS and revenue estimates. Michael Kors (KORS) was also a bottom mover on the back of a downgrade at Oppenheimer.

* WTI (Z8) SETTLES UNCHANGED AT $56.46/BBL; BRENT (F9) SETTLES $0.14 HIGHER AT $66.76/BBL. This week’s news that OPEC was mulling a supply cut of up to 1.4mln barrels per day continued to support the crude complex on Friday. At the margin, markets may have received a boost after surviving large inventory builds in the week too, Citi said. “While the price action is constructive, there is still some residual risk that the market will decide that the uptrend in US crude stocks is bearish after all, triggering a fresh round of disappointment,” Citi wrote. It also pointed out that book squaring in the WTI Z8 contract ahead of Monday’s contract expiry was a feature of trade on Friday. This week’s Baker Hughes reported oil up 2 rigs at 888, gas down 1 rig at 194, total rigs up 1 at 1082.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 11 TICKS HIGHER AT 119-05.  Although Treasury yields were lower by between 4-5.5bps across the curve, major curve spreads saw some modest steepening, with the exception of the 2s5s part of the curve. Continued Brexit newsflow helped support have FI in European trade as Cabinet members announced their resignations. The complex stabilised after the US cash equity opened, and the T-Note future was traversing sideways , dipping only on Trump supposedly positive on trade talks with China; however, after officials walked-back from Trump’s comments, there was some slight selling, though the T-Note remained near session highs.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: DXY: Softer than forecast US data looks set to keep pressure on the broad Usd, especially coming hot on the heels of some cautious comments about contagion from slower global growth via Fed’s Clarida and Kaplan, and with the former also asserting that rates are already close to neutral. Hence, the index has pulled back even further new 2018 peaks set earlier in the week, albeit partly due to external factors/moves/developments, and only just off sub-96.400 lows vs 97.704 at best, with the technical outlook more bearish if it closes below 96.590 (50% Fib) and having started the week around 97.000.

* GBP: Some much needed respite for Sterling that has been pulled from pillar to post, and mainly flogged from peaks hit on Tuesday and Wednesday following what seemed like a major Brexit breakthrough. To recap, UK and EU negotiators finally reached a compromise withdrawal agreement that included a back-stop to avoid a hard Irish boarder, but with no predetermined end date or mechanism for Britain to end the arrangement after transition. However, PM May managed to secure ‘majority’ Cabinet backing after a lengthy meeting before the walls started to fall apart in Whitehall on Thursday with 7 Government resignations, including Brexit Minister Raab himself. This sparked a more concerted move by Brexiteers, lead by ERG head Rees-Mogg, to oust the PM, but the no confidence motion has still not reached the 48 tally needed for a vote, and May got a Friday fillip as 5 other top/high profile members of her team decided to stay and rallied behind her. Gove and Fox also urged support from Parliament for the draft deal to provide May a life-line pending leadership challenge developments, and the Pound, with Cable currently above 1.2850 vs 1.2724 at worst, but still around 100 pips down from where it ‘opened’ and more than 2 big figures off best levels, while Eur/Gbp is above 0.8850 and a clutch of MAs.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: The commodity currencies are all ending Friday’s EU session and the week as a whole ahead of their US counterpart in line with the overall trend, but also as oil and metals prices rebound firmly, with crude extending its recovery to 2 days following almost 2 weeks in deep bear market territory. The Aud also had bullish data to provide momentum via a stellar labour report and recently climbed to a fresh 0.7300+ peak vs circa 0.7160 at the other extreme, while the Kiwi has largely tracked its antipodean peer to scale 0.6850 from just over 0.6700 at worst after some outperformance when the Aud/Nzd cross swooned to almost 1.0600 at one stage.

* JPY, EUR, CHF: All on course to end a volatile week with solid gains vs the Greenback, with the Jpy extending its recovery from 114.20 through 113.00 and not far from 112.50 as risk appetite waned on the aforementioned Brexit malaise, ongoing US-China/global trade issues, and Italian-EU budget dispute that appears likely to result in official proceedings next Wednesday. However, the single currency has managed to overcome earlier qualms and more evidence of a slowdown in German/Eurozone growth (in fact German GDP contracted 0.2% q/q in Q3) to reclaim 1.1400 vs a fresh ytd low circa 1.1215, while the Franc is back around parity vs 1.0130 or thereabouts at worst.

* EM: The Lira is off best levels, but still relatively bid after reports that the US could Turkish cleric Gulen in an attempt to assuage President Erdogan to adopt a less aggressive stance against Saudi Arabia over the Khashoggi killing. Usd/Try now pivoting 5.3300 within 5.3130-3940 trading parameters.

* COMING-UP: Monday: Data – No Tier 1 Data on the Calendar. Speakers – Fed’s Williams Tuesday: Data – German PPI; US Building Permits & Housing Starts. Speakers – BoE’s Carney, Cunliffe, Haldane and Saunders Wednesday: Data – US Durable Goods, Initial Jobless Claims and EIA Weekly Data Thursday: Data – No Tier 1 Data on the Calendar. Speakers – BoE’s Haldane and Saunders; ECB’s Mersch. Note: Early Market Closures due to Thanksgiving Friday: Data – German Detailed GDP and Flash PMI; EU Flash PMI; Canadian CPI; Baker Hughes Rig Count. Speakers – ECB’s de Guindos. Note: Early Market Closures due to Thanksgiving. Click here for the full RANsquawk Week In Focus report.

* CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: Previewing ECB minutes, RBA minutes, SARB meeting; reviewing Banxico. Click here for the full RANsquawk report.

subject: Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) says US economy is doing well and expects 3.25% GDP growth this year and 3.5% next year
content:
• He says wages have increased but not as much as would have expected; hard to get a reading on inflation by looking at wage pressures as they move simultaneously
  • Sees the current rate a little bit below neutral, getting to neutral is the "first order job" for the Fed
  • Need for accommodation is not really there anymore
  • Downside risk to inflation not very great
  • Current economic outlook has been quite good, financial stability risks look moderate
  • Stocks buybacks are a signal that businesses look forward to good business outlook
  • Yield curve is one of the many indicators the Fed looks at

subject: Fed's Kaplan (Dove, Non-voter) says increasing debt to GDP is a tailwind for now, but will become a headwind in the future; he adds global growth will be a little bit of a headwind and may spill to the US
Fed Vice Chair Clarida notes there is some volatility around stock markets at the moment, but no clear signal
content:
• Doesn't agree hikes are going too fast or too far, hikes have been gradual
  • Fed should be especially data dependent 
  • Current rate is below neutral, which should be between 2.5%-3.5%; being at neutral would make sense
  • Fed needs to factor in the global economy, global growth is relevant for his outlook on US economy; noted how IMF marked down growth projections
  • Still room to run in the labour market

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Gove, Fox, Grayling, Mourdant and Leadsom all decide to stay as UK political resignations abate
  • ERG sources suggest 48 letters need for no confidence vote have all been handed in to Brady
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Industrial Production, ECB’s Weidmann and Lane, Fed’s Evans

ASIA

Asia-Pac stocks traded indecisively as the region lacked fresh catalysts and as uncertainty regarding Brexit and US-China trade played on investor’s minds. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were choppy with outperformance of tech and mining names in Australia overshadowed by a lacklustre broader market, while the Japanese benchmark was subdued by mild flows into the JPY and after China Mofcom began an investigation into alleged dumping of machine tools by Japanese firms. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) swung between gains and losses after continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC which skipped OMOs for a 16th consecutive occasion, while participants were also tentative amid ongoing trade uncertainty after conflicting reports regarding the next round of China tariffs being placed on hold which USTR Lighthizer later denied. Finally, 10yr JGBs were mildly higher with prices underpinned amid an indecisive tone seen in stocks and with the BoJ also present in the market for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral for a 2nd consecutive week. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9377 (Prev. 6.9392)

PBoC said overall lending has kept to stable growth and that financing conditions of private and small firms improved. PBoC also commented that financial institutions should take steps to reasonably manage pace and intensity of credit supply, while they should also make full use of incentive measures for lending to private and small firms. (Newswires)

BREXIT

Ministerial Positions:

UK PM May said she has not appointed a new Brexit Minister yet, but she will do so in the coming days. (Newswires)

James Forsyth, Sun Columnist, confirmed that Michael Gove is staying. Times suggests that he will remain as Environment Secretary. (Twitter)

Fox, Grayling, Mourdant and Leadsom have all agreed to stay, as according to Sunday Times. (Newswires)

No Confidence:

Beth Rigby Sky Deputy Political Editor tweets, “Have this confirmed by a source close to the whips office. They are heading back to SW1. Source tells me it must now be likely that confidence vote happening. “Got to be close if not there already”. (Newswires)

Business Insider correspondent Adam Payne tweets, The ERG believes Graham Brady now has 48 letters, an ERG source tells me. (Newswires)

Scheduling:

Jennifer Rankin of the Guardian tweets "EU Brexit schedule now agreed. Sunday: special Brexit meeting EU27 ambassadors. Monday: special Brexit EU27 Europe ministers Wheels in motion for Sunday 25 November summit". (Newswires)

Northern Ireland:

DUP Deputy Leader said have to wait and see how things in the conservative party play out especially its leadership, while there were later reports in the Telegraph that suggested the UK Conservative Party power sharing alliance with DUP is said to be over unless PM May is replaced. (Newswires/Telegraph)

EU/UK/US

EU HICP Final YY Oct 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.2%)

EU HICP-X F&E Final YY Oct 1.2% (Prev. 1.3%)

EU HICP-X F,E,A&T Final YY Oct 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%)

TRADE

China's Ambassador to the US said the US is one of China's most important partners and that China will not stop reform and opening up. China’s Ambassador also commented that China is prepared to work with US and that accusations against China are based on alternative facts. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Republican and Democrat Senators file bipartisan bill seeking to suspend arms sales to Saudi Arabia in response to war in Yemen and killing of journalist. (Newswires)

North Korean Leader Kim inspected test of new high-tech tactical weapons, according to Yonhap citing North Korean state media. (Yonhap)

EQUITIES

European equities trade relatively flat (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) in the wake of mixed trade headlines overnight for the US and China. Performance across European indices is relatively equal whilst focus once again falls on the FTSE 100 (U/C) which remains at the whim of Brexit-inspired fluctuations in the GBP. Once again, potential upside for the index is being capped by losses in domestically focused banking names (RBS -3.0%, Lloyds -2.1%) as Brexit uncertainty continues to dampen investor sentiment.

In terms of sector specifics, most sectors are trading higher with mild outperformance seen in telecom names. Utilities started the session lower in the wake of yesterday’s ECJ decision which deemed the UK’s scheme for ensuring power supplies during the winter months as a violation of state aid rules. Other individual movers include Vivendi (+4.2%) sit at the top of the Stoxx 600 after posting impressive Q3 sales metrics and announcing a potential sale of part of their Universal Music Group division. Elsewhere, AstraZeneca (-2.3%) and Shire (-1.3%) have been seen lower throughout the session after both posting disappointing drug updates.

FX

GBP - The Pound is not the biggest net mover for a change, but still one of the most volatile and vulnerable as Cable pivots 1.2800 and Eur/Gbp trades between 0.8850-80. The fall-out from Wednesday’s Cabinet meeting continues as UK PM May strives to sell the Brexit draft, but facing a rising rebellion within the Conservative Party that appears to have reached the critical mass required to trigger a no confidence vote. However, some positive news with a key Minister deciding not to follow others out of the Government, as Gove opts to stay rather than go. In terms of technical impulses, Cable is holding above yesterday’s 1.2725 low, ahead of chart support around 1.2710-00 that protects mtd and ytd troughs at 1.2696 and 1.2662 respectively, while near term resistance is seen around 1.2836 before 1.2850, but 1 bn option expiries at 1.2800 could well exert more influence into the NY cut. For Eur/Gbp, several MAs form support blow 0.8850 and the 100 DMA at 0.8910 may hamper further gains if 0.8900 is breached.

NZD/AUD - Not quite zeroes from heroes, but the antipodean Dollars have pulled back from recent peaks amidst latest US-China trade headlines/reports that seem somewhat less constructive on the prospect of progress towards a deal that would prevent the next round of tariffs and reciprocal protection measures. The Kiwi has drifted back towards 0.6800 and Aud from another 0.7300 test to circa 0.7250, but with big option expiries in close proximity likely to keep the latter contained (2.4 bn at 0.7225 vs 1 bn at 0.7275).

JPY - Maintaining a firm underlying safe-haven bid as broad risk sentiment remains fragile and China is reportedly investigating machine dumping by Japan – Usd/Jpy near the bottom of a 113.20-65 range.

EUR/CAD/CHF - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the single currency keeping afloat of 1.1300 and eyeing a Fib at 1.1358, while the Loonie is holding recent recovery gains through 1.3200 as oil prices continue their rebound and the Franc meanders between 1.0075-50 vs 1.1000+ earlier this week when the broad Dollar and DXY were in the ascendency (index well above 97.000 vs just below the figure presently).

EM - The Lira is off best levels, but still relatively bid after reports that the US could Turkish cleric Gulen in an attempt to assuage President Erdogan to adopt a less aggressive stance against Saudi Arabia over the Khashoggi killing. Usd/Try now near the middle of a 5.3240-3940 band.

COMMODITIES

Gold (+0.2%) is trading relatively flat after hitting new weekly highs of USD 1218.39/oz earlier in the session; following uneventful overnight trade. Elsewhere, Shanghai Zinc prices have risen due to London Metal Exchange stockpiles falling to decade-low levels.

Brent (+1.3%) and WTI (+1.1%) are both in the green and continuing their rebound seen yesterday with WTI hovering around USD 57.00bbl. Energy newsflow remains light, post-yesterday's DoE report, however, Iraq’s North Oil Co. have announced that they have resumed Kiruk oil exports heading towards the Turkish port of Ceyhan. Looking ahead, the main highlight on the calendar will be the Baker Hughes rig count. Elsewhere, natural gas futures are relatively steady after their 19% decline yesterday which came in the wake of a 20% increase the day before.

FIXED INCOME

Relatively small extension to the downside in Gilts, to a fresh 122.82 Liffe low (-36 ticks on the day) as the Whitehall walkout ends, or at least abates, and PM May continues to staunchly defend the UK-EU withdrawal draft amidst a rising leadership challenge that seems on track to culminate in a confidence vote next Tuesday. Meanwhile, Bunds actually eked out a slender 1 tick gain, or rather marginal new Eurex top at 160.73 to inch a bit closer towards parity and Thursday’s close, and US Treasuries are now flat after some overnight undulations amidst choppy trade across Asia-Pac bourses. Ahead, ip data and more Fed speak, but broader risk sentiment continues to dominate and pre-weekend positioning will also be a factor as this US holiday-shortened, but still long week draws to an end.

However, UK markets are still very much prone to sharp and erratic moves/price swings on Brexit headlines as PM May continues to defend the withdrawal draft, and stress that the current/latest proposal is not the finished article but a stop-gap to operate during the transition phase, while the plot to oust her rumbles on.

UK PM May says she hasn't appointed a Brexit Secretary yet, and will do so in the coming days
Bunds: unwinding some Brexit and Italian budget premium
content: The 10 year German debt future was marked down 27 ticks from the off, but has pared losses since to trade back up at 160.72 vs yesterday’s 160.81 Eurex close amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty and budget wrangling between Italy and the EU ahead of the next official review from Brussels on Wednesday. Hence, only a tentative or token pull-back in Bunds as both issues remain very fluid, and the prospect of either breaking down or blowing up into a significant risk event persists. Ahead, Italian data and final Eurozone CPI may provide a distraction along with ECB commentary, but core bonds and financial markets in general are transfixed on the aforementioned unresolved matter, while keeping a close watch on unfolding global trade developments.

16th November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will13e covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac stocks traded indecisively as the region lacked fresh catalysts and as uncertainty regarding Brexit and US-China trade played on investor’s minds. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were choppy with outperformance of tech and mining names in Australia overshadowed by a lacklustre broader market, while the Japanese benchmark was subdued by mild flows into the JPY and after China Mofcom began an investigation into alleged dumping of machine tools by Japanese firms. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) swung between gains and losses after continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC which skipped OMOs for a 16th consecutive occasion, while participants were also tentative amid ongoing trade uncertainty after conflicting reports regarding the next round of China tariffs being placed on hold which USTR Lighthizer later denied. Finally, 10yr JGBs were mildly higher with prices underpinned amid an indecisive tone seen in stocks and with the BoJ also present in the market for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

FTSE

Ocado (OCDO LN) – The co. has said they see opportunities to make more deals with established grocers in Europe, South America and Asia, with the possibility of moving into other categories in retail. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

FirstGroup (FGP LN) – Chairman Hauser has dismissed calls by the co.’s leading shareholder to commit to a dividend immediately, replace members of the board and separate their US and UK assets. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 16th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US-Chinese trade relations in focus again after conflicting reports suggesting the next round of Chinese tariffs are being placed on hold, which USTR Lighthizer later denied
  • UK PM May said she will see this through and fight leadership challenge. UK PM May is yet to appoint a new Brexit Minister
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ CPI, US Industrial Production, ECB’s Draghi, Weidmann and Lane, Fed’s Evans

TRADE

US and China are to step up efforts to strike G20 truce on trade and reports added that US Trade Representative Lightizer told some industry executives the next tranche of China tariffs are already on hold. However, Lighthizer later denied the reports that China tariffs have been put on hold. (FT/Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said US is still planning to raise tariffs on China to 25% in January and that he does not expect a full China deal by January. Ross also commented that the meeting between Xi and Trump at the G20 summit is to focus on "the big picture", although he still expects an eventual China deal. (Newswires)

US Administration official said it is unlikely for breakthroughs on trade with China at the G20 summit, while the official added it is too early to tell if China’s response to US demands will lead the US to suspend tariff increases in January and that China's offers to the US should be viewed cautiously. (Newswires)

China's Ambassador to the US said the US is one of China's most important partners and that China will not stop reform and opening up. China’s Ambassador also commented that China is prepared to work with US and that accusations against China are based on alternative facts. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asia-Pac stocks traded indecisively as the region lacked fresh catalysts and as uncertainty regarding Brexit and US-China trade played on investor’s minds. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were choppy with outperformance of tech and mining names in Australia overshadowed by a lacklustre broader market, while the Japanese benchmark was subdued by mild flows into the JPY and after China Mofcom began an investigation into alleged dumping of machine tools by Japanese firms. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) swung between gains and losses after continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC which skipped OMOs for a 16th consecutive occasion, while participants were also tentative amid ongoing trade uncertainty after conflicting reports regarding the next round of China tariffs being placed on hold which USTR Lighthizer later denied. Finally, 10yr JGBs were mildly higher with prices underpinned amid an indecisive tone seen in stocks and with the BoJ also present in the market for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral for a 2nd consecutive week. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9377 (Prev. 6.9392)

PBoC said overall lending has kept to stable growth and that financing conditions of private and small firms improved. PBoC also commented that financial institutions should take steps to reasonably manage pace and intensity of credit supply, while they should also make full use of incentive measures for lending to private and small firms. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May said she will see this through and fight leadership challenge, while she added she is going to do her job of getting the best deal for Britain and will bring the deal back for a vote in the House of Commons. Furthermore, UK PM May said she has not appointed a new Brexit Minister yet. (Newswires)

It was reported that Environmental Minister Michael Gove was expected to resign yesterday but this did not materialise. (Times)

DUP Deputy Leader said have to wait and see how things in the conservative party play out especially its leadership, while there were later reports in the Telegraph that suggested the UK Conservative Party power sharing alliance with DUP is said to be over unless PM May is replaced. (Newswires/Telegraph)

ERG source reported that there were not yet enough letters to trigger a no confidence vote in PM May, although stated numbers have certainly gone up but are seen to still be in the 30s. (Twitter)

Italian government draft amendment allows unlisted banks and non-financial companies to opt out of international accounting standards and includes lending operation, according to sources. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets were range-bound amid a light calendar with no tier-1 releases or speakers scheduled. This kept the DXY flat near the 97.00 level and provided GBP/USD with some much-needed respite from the prior day’s cliff dive which was triggered by an exodus of ministers, while reports in the Telegraph also suggested the Conservative Party deal with DUP is over unless PM May is replaced. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were subdued by the indecisive risk tone and commodity-linked currencies held firm amid continued gains in the energy and metal prices.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were higher overnight in which WTI continued its rebound to approach the USD 57.00/bbl level to the upside, while nat gas futures outperformed the energy space as snowy conditions in eastern US help prices nurse some of the prior day’s heavy losses. Elsewhere, gold prices were flat due to an uneventful greenback and copper kept afloat amid early strength in Chinese commodities, as well as outperformance in the mainland China bourses.
 

GEOPOLITICS

US Republican and Democrat Senators file bipartisan bill seeking to suspend arms sales to Saudi Arabia in response to war in Yemen and killing of journalist. (Newswires)

North Korean Leader Kim inspected test of new high-tech tactical weapons, according to Yonhap citing North Korean state media. (Yonhap)


US

Treasuries traded with a positive bias in choppy trade with Brexit news flow increasing appeal of safe-haven fixed income. However, in later trade after the US and China announced intensifying trade talks and after US Trade Representative Lightizer said China tariffs have been placed on hold (later denied), risk-tone became more constructive with Treasuries moving to session lows as stocks moved higher. There where was little reaction after a decent retail sales report. There were some chatter that CTAs were covering shorts, helping to support the complex. The Treasury announced that it will sell USD 11bln in 10-year TIPS in next Wednesday's reopening, and it will sell USD 42bln 3-month bills and USD 35bln 6-month bills Monday. The curve was steeper at settlement with the exception of 2s5s. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 2 ticks higher at 118-26.

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dove) said need to keep keen eye on data to avoid raising rates too fast or not far enough and suggested they should proceed cautiously, while he added that conditions warrant "final steps" for implementing a neutral rate which is where we want to be and sees the neutral rate between 2.5% and 3.5%. Furthermore, Bostic commented that the Fed has been removing forward guidance statements because it is not certain about policy direction and that businesses have told him they are delaying investment decisions amid tariffs. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-voter, Dove) said rates are pretty close to neutral today and that he is sympathetic with the need to find a way to open markets for free trade. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks are subdued amid lack of drivers and as momentum from Wall St waned
content:
Asia-Pac stocks trade indecisive with the region lacking fresh catalysts and as the tailwind from the broad gains in US gradually waned. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) failed to hold on to initial gains with outperformance of mining names in Australia overshadowed by a lacklustre broader market, while the Japanese benchmark is pressured by mild flows into the JPY and after China Mofcom began an investigation into alleged dumping of machine tools by Japanese firms. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) are softer after continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC which skipped OMOs for a 16th consecutive occasion, while participants are also tentative amid ongoing trade uncertainty after conflicting reports regarding the next round of China tariffs being placed on hold which USTR Lighthizer later denied.

FX markets are range-bound amid a light calendar with no tier-1 releases or speakers scheduled, which has kept the DXY flat near the 97.00 level. This provided GBP/USD with some respite from the prior day’s cliff dive which was triggered by an exodus of ministers including Brexit Secretary Raab and Secretary of State for Work and Pensions Esther McVey, while reports in the Telegraph also suggested the Conservative Party deal with DUP is over unless PM May is replaced. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are subdued by the cautious risk tone and commodity-linked currencies are mildly supported following the recent rebound in crude and upside in metals.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are mildly higher with prices underpinned as sentiment in Asia deteriorated and with the BoJ also present in the market for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

content:

- Co. October load factor rose 1.7ppts Y/Y to 81.8%. (Newswires)

- Co. units ink shipbuilding contract to build 10 bulk carriers for about CNY 3.6bln. (Newswires)

HNA Holdings (521 HK)
- HNA Infrastructure (357 HK) is planning to acquire property management firm from HNA Group for CNY 1.02bln. (Newswires)

Trade Related
- US and China are to step up efforts to strike G20 truce on trade to curb their trade war and there were reports that US Trade Representative Lightizer told some industry executives the next tranche of China tariffs are already on hold. However, Lighthizer later denied reports that China tariffs have been put on hold. (FT/Newswires)
- US Commerce Secretary Ross said US is still planning to raise tariffs on China to 25% in January, while Ross had also commented he does not expect a full China deal by January and that the meeting between Xi and Trump at the G20 summit is to focus on "the big picture", although he still expects an eventual China deal. (Newswires)
- US Administration official said it is unlikely for breakthroughs on trade with China at the G20 summit, while the official added it is too early to tell if Chinese response to US demands will lead the US to suspend tariff increases in January and that China's offers to the US should be viewed cautiously. (Newswires)
- China’s Mofcom reiterated it hopes US and China can resolve trade dispute through dialogue and negotiations. (Newswires)

Other News
- China’s Shandong province plans to establish a CNY 10bln fund to support listed firms. (Newswires)
